questions.text:
True about paraquat poisoning:
1. Pulmonary fibrosis
2. Oral ulcers
3. Acute tubular necrosis
4. Constriction of pupil
5. Hyperthermia
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paraquat poisoning causes Oral ulcers, Acute tubular necrosis and Pulmonary fibrosis. Pupil is normal and there will be hypothermia.

Paraquat is used as herbicide and weed-killer.

SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS:

Local: Irritation and inflammation of skin, nails, cornea, conjunctivae and nasal mucosa.

G.I.T.: Oropharyngeal ulceration and corrosion, nausea, vomiting, haematemesis, diarrhoea; painful mucosal ulceration, dysphagia, aphonia, perforation of oesophagus, mediastinitis and pneumothorax.

Kidneys: Oliguria or non-oliguric renal failure due to acute tubular necrosis; proximal tubular dysfunction.

Lungs: Cough, haemoptysis, dyspnoea due to pulmonary oedema, haemorrhage and fibrosis in later stages

Pancreas: Pancreatitis.

Liver: Centrilobular hepatic necrosis and cholestasis.

C.V.S.: Hypovolaemia, shock, arrhythmias.

C.N.S.: Late coma, convulsions, cerebral oedema.

Adrenal: Insufficiency due to necrosis.

Bone marrow: Early - Polymorphonuclear leucocytosis: late - anaemia

Hypokalaemia and Hypothermia are Associated with paraquat poisoning.

Key Takeaway:
Paraquat poisoning leads to oral mucosal damage, pulmonary fibrosis, and renal tubular injury, but not pupillary changes or hyperthermia.

Explanation:

Organophosphate compounds are commonly used insecticides that inhibit acetylcholinesterase. Among the listed options, Endrin is an organochlorine compound, not an organophosphate.

  1. Organophosphorus(OP) compounds[OPC]
    • Alkyl phosphates → HETP, TEPP, OMPA, Malathion etc.
    • Aryl phoshates → Parathion(Follidol), Methyl Parathion(Metacide), Diazinon(Tik-20), Paraoxon etc.
  2. Organochlorine(OC) compounds → Endrin, Dieldrin, Aldrin, DDT, Gamaxane, BHC, Lindane, Endosulfan, Toxaphene etc.
  3. Carbamates → Carbaryl, Aldicarb, Baygon, Aminocarb, Ficam, Propoxur. Carbofuran etc.
  4. Plant products → Pyrethrins, Rotenone and Nicotine
    • Pyrethrins are active extracts of the Chrysanthemum plant.
    • Pyrethroids are synthetic analogues

Explanation of other options:

Diazinon (Option A): Organophosphate compound used as insecticide; inhibits acetylcholinesterase.

Malathion (Option C): Organophosphate pesticide used in agriculture and public health.

Parathion (Option D): Highly toxic organophosphate; acts as a cholinesterase inhibitor.

Key Takeaway:
Endrin is an organochlorine pesticide, whereas Diazinon, Malathion, and Parathion are organophosphate compounds that inhibit cholinesterase activity.

questions.text: All are features of organophosphorus poisoning, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

OP compounds usually cause miosis, not mydriasis.

Signs & symptoms of OP poisoning:

I. Muscarinic manifestations: These symptoms can be easily remembered by the acronym SLUDGE: Salivation, Lacrimation, Urination, Defaecation, Gastrointestinal distress and Emesis.

  1. Bronchial tree: Bronchoconstriction, increased bronchial secretions, dyspnoea, cyanosis, pulmonary oedema.
  2. G.I.T.: Anorexia, salivation, nausea, vomiting, cramps, diarrhoea, faecal incontinence, tenesmus. Pancreatitis may develop.
  3. Sweat glands: Increased sweating.
  4. Salivary glands: Increased salivation.
  5. Lacrimal glands: Increased lacrimation.
  6. V.S.: Bradycardia or tachycardia, arrhythmias, conduction blocks, hypotension.
  7. Pupils: Miosis, occasionally unequal or dilated.
  8. Ciliary body: Blurred vision.
  9. Bladder: Urinary incontinence.

II. Nicotinic manifestations:

  1. Striated muscle: Initial stimulus results in contraction. Later there is paralysis due to persistent depolarisation. Muscle weakness is due to accumulation of acetylcholine. Muscular fasciculations, cramps, weakness, areflexia.
  2. Sympathetic ganglia: Hypertension, tachycardia, pallor, mydriasis.

III. CNS manifestations: Restlessness, emotional lability, headache, tremors, anxiety, drowsiness, confusion, slurred speech, ataxia, generalised weakness, coma, convulsions, depression of respiratory and cardiovascular centres.

In some cases, only muscarinic or nicotinic or CNS effects are seen, but most cases show a combination of all three. Nicotinic effects are seen in 10 to 20% cases only.

Explanation of other options:

Diazinon (Option A): Organophosphate compound used as insecticide; inhibits acetylcholinesterase.

Malathion (Option C): Organophosphate pesticide used in agriculture and public health.

Parathion (Option D): Highly toxic organophosphate; acts as a cholinesterase inhibitor.

Key Takeaway:
Endrin is an organochlorine pesticide, whereas Diazinon, Malathion, and Parathion are organophosphate compounds that inhibit cholinesterase activity.

questions.text: All are true of OPC poisoning, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Atropinization: Atropine blocks the muscarinic manifestations and has no effect on nicotinic receptors(on muscle weakness or paralysis) and does not affect the rate of regeneration of inhibited AChE.

Dose: 2-4 mg IV(0.05-0.2 mg/kg in children) repeated after every 5-15 minutes till atropinization, the dose should be adjusted to maintain this effect for at least 24 hours(maintenance dose: 0.02-0.05 mg/kg).

Explanation of other options:

Anti-cholinesterase agents (Option A): OPCs inhibit acetylcholinesterase, causing ACh buildup.

Bradycardia (Option B): Seen due to excess acetylcholine acting on muscarinic receptors.

Paralysis (Option D): A late nicotinic effect due to persistent depolarization at neuromuscular junctions.

choices.text: Reported in all cases of OP poisoning

questions.text: Which of the following characterises the intermediate syndrome in OP poisoning?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intermediate Syndrome:

In some cases of OP poisoning after one to four days muscle weakness and paralysis characterised by motor cranial nerve palsies, weakness of neck flexor and proximal limb muscles and acute respiratory paresis are seen due to prolonged cholinesterase inhibition and muscle necrosis.

It does not respond to oximes or atropine.

Delayed Syndrome(Now called Delayed encephalopathy and neuropathy syndrome): It sometimes occur 1-4 weeks after poisoning due to nerve demyelination and is characterised by flaccid weakness and atrophy of distal limb muscles or spasticity and ataxia. It rapidly progresses to a flaccid paresis which can ascend similar to Guillain-Barre syndrome. Reflexes are diminished. The disease may progress for 2 to 3 months and muscle wasting occurs.

Explanation of other options:

Symptoms and signs of cholinergic excess (Option A): Characteristic of the acute phase, not intermediate syndrome.

Weakness of neck extensors (Option C): A feature, but not the defining hallmark.

Reported in all cases of OP poisoning (Option D): IMS occurs only in a subset of patients, not universally.

Key Takeaway:
 The intermediate syndrome in OP poisoning lacks a specific antidote and is managed supportively, mainly with respiratory support.
